content.description: An ecologist collected a large sample of forest soil and distributed it evenly into two samples, sample A and sample B. Sample A was placed in a temperature control chamber that was maintained at the forest’s average high temperature. Sample B was placed in a separate temperature control chamber that was maintained at \(5\degree C\) above the forest’s average high temperature. Both samples were kept in their chambers for 60 days and were watered with only enough sterile water to keep the soil moist. After 60 days, soil from both samples was removed and tested for ammonia levels. Results are shown in Table 1.
content.question: Table 1. Ammonia Levels\(\ \left(\text{mg}/\text{kg},\ \pm2SE_{\overline{x}}\right)\) Sample A Sample B 11.4 \(±\) 0.7 3.3 \(±\) 0.4 Which of the following is the best explanation of the ammonia level in sample B shown in Table 1?

choices.label: The ammonia level was lower in sample B because the elevated temperature caused the ammonia to evaporate into the atmosphere.
The ammonia level was lower in sample B because the added water washed ammonia out of the soil.
The ammonia level was lower in sample B because the increased temperature reduced the number of nitrogen-fixing bacteria in the soil.
The ammonia level was lower in sample B because the elevated temperature caused the ammonia molecules to break down into simple atoms.

content.answer: The ammonia level was lower in sample B because the increased temperature reduced the number of nitrogen-fixing bacteria in the soil.

skill.text: 6.D: Explain the relationship between experimental results and larger biological concepts, processes, or theories.
